entry.title: Re: Intercompany Billing related to reassigned revenues i...
entry.content:
Dear @Max_H_ ,

Regarding your questions I would like to provide following answers

1) Reassign Revenues from one WBS-element to another (different company code) via App: Reassign costs and revenues
Reassignment of revenues across company codes is supported by the App. For intercompany revenue reassignment please acknowledge that this Management Accounting posting will also show up in the Account Line Items and may influence local stat accounting. The intercompany posting in Management Accounting is offset with an ICO clearing account posting.
Please refer to 
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/intercompany-cost-allocations-in-s-4hana-cloud/ba-p/13442721 
for further details.

2) Create intercompany billing request + invoice
As you mentioned the process for costs is totally fine.
The described behavior for revenues is not supported. The consideration of revenue reassignments is considered as a bug on which is currently being worked upon. Intercompany Billing for Cross Company Cost Accounting postings (4AN) should not be used. Depending on the use case cross company revenue reassignment - in case needed and compliant - other scenarios need to be used (eg manual journal entry).

Best regards
Thorsten

entry.title: Re: MRP Type V1
entry.content:
MRP Type V1 stands for Manual Reorder Point Planning with External Requirements. It behaves differently from standard MRP types like PD:

  • It’s primarily consumption-based, not requirement-driven.
  • It does not perform full rescheduling checks like PD does.
  • It may ignore future reservations if they fall outside the reorder logic or rescheduling horizon.

As a result, when you run MRP with V1:

  • the system may see existing POs as unnecessary if stock is above the reorder point.
  • It may suggest canceling POs even if future reservations exist.

Recommended approach is switch to MRP Type PD (Planning Based on Requirements) which performs rescheduling checks and considers future reservations. It generates exception messages like:

  • 10 – Bring process forward
  • 15 – Postpone process

This ensures POs are rescheduled, not canceled, when demand shifts.

Configure Rescheduling Horizon and Tolerance via transactions OPPQ or OMDW to set:

Rescheduling horizon: Defines how far into the future MRP looks for requirements
Tolerance values: Controls when exception messages are triggered

This helps MRP recognize valid future demand and propose rescheduling instead of deletion.

In short, the summary would be

entry.title: SAP SuccessFactors Data Loader
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I read the below in an article and just need to know if we really have any tools like this in SF.

*****************************************************************************************************************

SAP SuccessFactors Data Loader

  • Use Case: While this isn’t a SAP solution outside of SuccessFactors, it’s an important tool for ensuring that data is in the right format when importing into Employee Central.
  • How it Helps:
    • Data Formatting: SAP SuccessFactors Data Loader requires the data to be in a specific format. Using tools like SAP Data Services or SAP MDG to format the data before uploading can ensure smooth integration.
    • Validation Checks: The Data Loader also performs basic validation checks on the data to ensure that it conforms to SuccessFactors standards before proceeding with the upload.

******************************************************************************************************************************

Appreciate your response on this.

Regards,

SR

entry.title: Re: SSO Configuration Issue When Accessing S/4HANA Public...
entry.content:
Based on your details, yes, your understanding is correct. There is no need to configure direct trust between SAP Build Work Zone and SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Instead, both systems independently establish trust with the same Identity Provider, typically the SAP Cloud Identity Services. Please note, Build Work Zone can authenticate to IAS via OpenID Connect for user login but the backend destination to S/4HANA must use an authentication method that supports token forwarding e.g., SAML Assertion or OAuth 2.0.

The SAML Assertion setup must however, align with IAS and S4HANA trust configurations, including metadata exchange, certificates, and application registration. Which might be the issue here. If you followed the SAML Assertion configuration tutorial for N5T_Starter_rt_tiles, I suggest checking and potentially evaluating the following steps to ensure they are correct:

  • First, make sure the SAML fields like Destination, Audience, Recipient, and NameIdentifier are properly set to match your application settings.
  • Then the SAML response status should indicate success.
  • Also, make sure to Check the certificate used to sign the SAML assertion matches what your app expects.
  • After that, confirm the attributes in the assertion map correctly to what your application requires e.g., email, user id.
  • If needed, adjust attribute mappings in your SAML provider to fit your app's expectations.
  • Finally, ensure logout requests’ SessionIndex and NameID match the original assertion for proper sign-out.

If you still encounter the same error, I suggest you review your SAML/OAuth setup in IAS, destination configuration in BTP, and check token exchange logs on both sides.

Let me know if that works for you.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAC Story - Dropdown for property of Date dimension.
entry.content:
While using an SAC Story on top of a Planning Model, and with the help of @nikhil (link below), I am able to successfully add properties of a generic dimension to a Dropdown widget. I am now wanting to do the same for the Date dimension property "CALMONTH".

However, after copying the working code, and where applicable changing it to use the dimension "Date" and the property "CALMONTH", the dropdown remains unpopulated on initialization.  I have tried using a different Date property and also recreated a new model, but I get the same blank Dropdown result each time.

Can anyone please advise where things are going wrong?  Or can anyone please confirm that the below code is working in their environment?

Otherwise failing that, does anyone have another method of populating a Date dimension's property in a Dropdown?

Thanks

Anton

var dimDate = PlanningModel_1.getMembers("Date");
var CALMONTHmemberId = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);

for( var i = 0; i< dimDate.length; i++ )
	{		
		var currentCALMONTH = dimDate[i].properties.CALMONTH;
		if(CALMONTHmemberId.indexOf(currentCALMONTH) === -1 && currentCALMONTH)
			{
			   CALMONTHmemberId.push(currentCALMONTH);
			   Dropdown_CALMONTH.addItem(currentCALMONTH);
			}
	}

 

(Working solution - https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/sac-story-use-dropdown-for-dimension-property/qaa-p/14177305/emcs_t/S2h8ZW1haWx8dG9waWNfc3Vic2NyaXB0aW9ufE1FNldFWDlSNjVLNjF8MTQxNzczMDV8U1VCU0NSSVBUSU9OU3xoSw#M4922567)

entry.title: Re: Sales document type / Order type is not visible in T-...
entry.content:
To make Sales Document Type visible in J7LTSL, follow this structured approach:

Step 1: Activate SD Interface Mapping

Use Function Modules as under, not T-codes:

These FM's are part of IS-REA (Recycling Administration) and are used to map SD documents to REA categories. Ask your ABAP team to check if these FM's are active and properly linked in your REA customizing.

Step 2: Maintain REA Category Mapping

Use T-code J7L1 or J7L3 to assign REA categories to Sales Document Types and ensure correct mapping of item categories and REA condition types

Step 3: Check REA Document Type Settings

Use T-code J7L2 or J7L5 to define REA document types and link them to SD document types and REA categories

In short, the summary is

entry.title: Re: [SAP Crystal Reports Developer for Visual Studio] Ass...
entry.content:
Hi Charles,

Here's a few links to add to your favourite list:

All of the relevant info, What's new, what's been fixed, licensing, release notes, etc.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/crystalreports/3354091173.html?locale=en-US

Direct link to downloads:

https://origin.softwaredownloads.sap.com/public/site/index.html

There are multiple reasons why you should upgrade to the latest

1. As of the end of 2025 SAP will no long make 32 bit runtime available, time to build your project in 64 bit, no reason why to support 32 bit applications anymore since all PC mother boards support 64 bit applications

2. Security updates are embedded in latest SP's, this is for your own security and your users.

3. More important is the deprecation of 3rd party dependencies, Windows Framework versions and other 3rd party dependencies. Currently SAP CR for VS only supports 4.7 and 4.8 Framework, Microsoft has deprecated older versions and CR for VS follows Microsoft's supported runtime.

To assist you in upgrading see this blog I wrote:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/upgrading-a-visual-studio-2008-gt-2022-net-project-with-the-latest-cr-net/ba-p/13469215

So to be Windows Compliant you really need to keep your project runtime updated to the latest SP's

Hope that helps and convinces you to upgrade to the latest SP 38 runtime.

Note: SP 29 is now 5 years old...

Don

entry.title: 🚀 SAP Inside Track Pune 2025 – We are coming soon!
entry.content:
After the overwhelming success of our very first SAP Inside Track Pune in 2024, we’re thrilled to announce that SIT Pune is returning in 2025 for its second edition! 🎉
Last year, we saw an incredible gathering of over 250 participants, 20+ speakers, and an amazing group of volunteers who made the event truly unforgettable. The energy, knowledge sharing, and community spirit were simply unmatched – and we can’t wait to do it all over again.
 
What to expect in 2025?
  • Inspiring sessions from industry experts 🧠
  • Networking with SAP professionals, enthusiasts, and innovators 🤝
  • Real-world use cases, demos, and interactive discussions 💡
  • Plenty of fun, community bonding, and surprises 🎯
📅 Date & Venue: Coming soon – keep an eye on this space!
📍 City: Pune, Maharashtra
 
Whether you’re a seasoned SAP professional or just starting your journey, SIT Pune 2025 will be your chance to connect, learn, and contribute to one of the most vibrant SAP communities in India.
Stay tuned for more updates – and get ready to be part of something amazing again!
 
#SITPune2025 #SAPCommunity #SAPInsideTrack #sapcommunitypune
 
 
Best Regards,
SAP Community Pune Core Team

entry.title: Re: I want PO in 2 different language for same vendor as...
entry.content:
SAP uses the communication language maintained in the vendor master record to determine the print language of the PO. Specifically:

  • the field EKKO-SPRAS (PO header language) is derived from the vendor’s language setting
  • This language also populates the output language (NAST-SPRAS) used during print preview

So if the vendor master is set to Chinese, the PO prints in Chinese. If set to German, it prints in German—even for the same vendor number.

What you can do is you can have two Purchase Orgs (ex.CN01 & DE01); one for Chinese and the other for German. In Vendor master, for each Purchase Orgs, assign the respective language

entry.title: Master Royalties and Commissions Settlements with SAP Cloud ERP & SAP Subscription Billing
entry.content:
Managing and charging services effectively in a subscription-based business model is crucial for sustained revenue and customer satisfaction. SAP Subscription Billing supports you in handling these aspects by offering intuitive solutions to manage your subscription business efficiently. When integrated with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, it empowers organizations to streamline their financial processes. This integration also facilitates efficient and transparent management of complex subsequent settlement processes, such as royalties, internal, and external commissions in an automated manner. Understanding this synergy can transform how your business handles subscription services and the associated settlements, leading to optimized operations and improved financial outcomes.

Exploring Different Settlement Options
1. Intercompany Royalties: 
This settlement option is designed to manage royalties between different entities within the same corporate structure. When one company in a corporate group uses a product or service owned by another entity, intercompany royalties compensate the owning entity. This process ensures precise and compliant revenue distribution within corporate groups, enhancing financial accuracy and facilitating intercompany reconciliation.
2. External Royalties: 
Businesses often need to settle royalties with external entities or licensors who own certain intellectual properties or products that are included in the businesses' own offerings to their customers. These royalties are crucial for fulfilling legal obligations to licensors and securing continuous usage rights for commercially lucrative intellectual properties.
3. Internal Commissions: 
Motivating sales teams through well-structured commission plans can directly impact the success of any business. Internal commissions are calculated based on sales performance and are pivotal in driving sales personnel to achieve their targets. This settlement process ensures that commissions are distributed fairly, based on clear conditions set within the agreement.
4. External Commissions: 
Similar to internal commissions but involving external partners, such as sales agents that help drive sales from outside the company. This commission model must ensure that these external partners are rewarded appropriately for their contributions to driving the company’s revenue, thereby fostering a healthy and profitable external partnership.

Unlocking Robust Settlement Management Capabilities 
The integration of SAP Subscription Billing with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition enables organizations to unlock advanced tools for managing settlements efficiently. Through the integration scenario Subscription Management with Sales Billing (scope item 57Z), your business can access essential subsequent processes such as:

  • Royalties Settlement for Sales (55I): This scope item facilitates the comprehensive management of intercompany and external royalty settlements. Learn more about Royalties Settlement for Sales.
  • Sales Commissions - External Sales Representative (2TT): Seamlessly handles the settlements of external sales commissions . This scope item supports the management agreements with external sales agents, ensuring accurate and timely settlements aligned with business goals. Explore Sales Commissions for External Representatives.
  • Internal Commissions Settlement for Sales (3TD): Supports internal settlements of sales commissions, enabling businesses to manage employee incentives effectively and promote a performance-driven sales environment. More on Internal Commissions Settlement for Sales.


Condition contract, a central object in Settlement Management, manages all necessary conditions required for settlement, fostering an efficient and transparent process. By leveraging the above mentioned scope items, companies can ensure that their settlement processes are not only comprehensive but are also finely tuned to their specific business requirements. To accommodate variations from the default settlement process, each scope item comes with process variants. See the respective test scripts for details via the links above.

Conclusion 
Integrating SAP Subscription Billing with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition amplifies your operational efficiency. It streamlines the settlement aspect of your business. With robust features and seamless integration, the solution ensures your financial settlement processes are automated, making your operations effortlessly smooth and efficient.

Related Information 
Explore deeper into each specific settlement process:

  • Royalties Settlement 
  • Internal Commissions Settlement 
  • External Commissions Settlement

entry.title: SAP Cloud Print Manager (CPM) and SAP RISE
entry.content:
Hello,
we have SAP RISE (hosted by SAP) and we want to print form RISE in our local Network.
I found the following article about CPM.
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/cloud-print-manager-for-pull-integration-installation-and-configuration/ba-p/13334437

There I found these sentence:
"The Cloud Print Manager for Pull Integration (CPM) was initially developed for SAP S/4HANA Public
Cloud systems. For On Premise systems, several adoptions were implemented (available in 2024), which will be described in SAP Note 3420465 - Print queues in on-premise systems. This note explain the differences between the Cloud / On Premise setup and there is document attached for enabling CPM in OnPrem Systems."

I would interpret this as follows: If you follow note 3420465, you can also use CPM in a RISE environment.

Is this correct?

We have several locations, each with their own printers.
Would it be possible to install a separate CPM at each location and connect it to RISE? In other words, connect 1-n CPMs to one RISE system (one for each location)?

Thanks

entry.title: Re: Behavior validation messages are not displayed
entry.content: Since the PREPARE is executed during initial CREATE and further SAVE, it is handled by the action that creates the state messages. In this case it is the defined validation and here you can control the generation of the messages by adding create, update or both on the field that is used for the validation.

@Lakshmipathi has explained how it works in SAP standard. I would not recommend to set up a separate purchasing organization just to maintain a different vendor communication language. That is an overkill and a misuse of purchasing organizations. 

Your requirement is not standard. Additionally printouts are typically heavily customized. Therefore it should be quite straight forward to implement your requirement with a custom printing program.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

Do you know how to achieve that?

entry.title: Re: Refurbishment Process
entry.content:
Yes, refurbishment processes are supported in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Not sure, what type of refurbishment you are looking.
For information, below are the types of Refurbishment Processes supported in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

  1. Internal Equipment Refurbishment
  2. External Vendor Refurbishment
  3. Two-Tier ERP Refurbishment
  4. Customer Equipment Refurbishment

entry.title: Re: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into the about our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
@bjoern_panter  thank you for the quick response.

I checked the SAP note 3578329 already (which provide a great overview for many object types), but in the current version 5, InApp-Tools or KeyUser-Tools are not mentioned.

We are working with S4HANA Release 2023 Private Cloud Edition Feature Stack 2. 
Our concept is:

  • create Custom Fields and extend business context via "Custom Fields App" 
  • create new business logic by using BADI definitions (which are available in "Custom Logic App") but implement via ADT or classic SE18/SE19

Regards, Thomas F!

entry.title: Re: Crystal runtime not respecting Isolate Report/Page se...
entry.content:
Hi Simi,

I've been doing some testing and I discover you are correct, there is a bug.

Before I go on though please note when using Legacy mode you get this warning in the Designer when exporting:

Change your code to use Standard mode and adjust the report to match your requirements.

Also, I'm using RAS to export but I don't think it makes a difference using Shared() or RAS() to export.

I'll get R&D to look into this issue for you.

As a work around, and I now it's going to be time consuming but this does work:

Open each report in CRD and then select File.... Export... Report Export Options and then select CSV.

Enable your option here, once you select CSV:

Save the report and then use RAS to get those saved export options:

if (ExportTypeSelected == "crReportExportFormatCharacterSeparatedValues")
#region CSV
{
    // This works do not alter
    // this gets the report name and sets the export name to be the same less the extension
    string outputFileName = "";
    string MyRptName = rpt.FileName.ToString();
    outputFileName = MyRptName.Substring(9, rpt.FileName.Length - 9);
    outputFileName = outputFileName.Substring(0, (outputFileName.Length - 3)) + "csv";
    try
    {
        if (File.Exists(outputFileName))
        {
            File.Delete(outputFileName);
        }

        ////CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel. RasRTFExpOpts = new RTFWordExportFormatOptions();
        CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.CharacterSeparatedValuesExportFormatOptions RasCSVExpOpts = new CharacterSeparatedValuesExportFormatOptions();

        try
        {
            RasCSVExpOpts = rptClientDoc.get_SavedExportOptions(CrReportExportFormatEnum.crReportExportFormatCharacterSeparatedValues);
        }
        catch (Exception ex)
        {
            btnSQLStatement.Text = "No Export options saved: " + ex.Message;
            //return;
        }

        // Set them now:
        RasCSVExpOpts.Delimiter = "?";
        RasCSVExpOpts.Separator = "|";
        //RasCSVExpOpts.ExportMode = CrCSVExportModeEnum.crCSVExportModeStandard;
        //RasCSVExpOpts.GroupSectionsOption = CrCSVExportSectionsOptionEnum.crCSVExportSectionsOptionExport;
        //RasCSVExpOpts.ReportSectionsOption = CrCSVExportSectionsOptionEnum.crCSVExportSectionsOptionExportIsolated;

        // Save the udpated info
        if (RasCSVExpOpts != null)
            rptClientDoc.set_SavedExportOptions(CrReportExportFormatEnum.crReportExportFormatCharacterSeparatedValues, RasCSVExpOpts);
        // note: you do need to save the report document to see these changes

        CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.ExportOptions exportOpts1 = new CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.ExportOptions();
        exportOpts1.ExportFormatType = CrReportExportFormatEnum.crReportExportFormatCharacterSeparatedValues;
        exportOpts1.FormatOptions = RasCSVExpOpts;

        // And Export
        rptClientDoc.PrintOutputController.ExportEx(exportOpts1).Save(outputFileName, true);
        MessageBox.Show("Export to CSV Completed", "", MessageBoxButtons.OK, MessageBoxIcon.Information);

    }
    catch (Exception ex)
    {
        btnSQLStatement.Text = "ERROR: " + ex.Message;
        return;
    }
}
#endregion CSV

Of course this doesn't give your users the option to set the Group Isolation option, the rest should be able to be set in your code.

It appears the Group Isolation option is being ignored.

Don

entry.title: Re: SAC Story - Dropdown for property of Date dimension.
entry.content:
@antonclv19 

PlanningModel_1.getMembers() is only supported for generic dimensions. Date is not a generic dimension and hence this will not work.
 
You can just create a static dropdown for Date. Months are only 1-12. Also why don't you use standard Input control features to filter the Table.
 
 
Nikhil

entry.title: Re: APK file from MDK app, signature verification failed
entry.content: @Jakub_Szaek When you created your sigining profile in the cloud what expiration did you use?  There was an issue when using the default expiration of 25 years that could be worked around by selecting a lower expiration (like 24 years).  I would suggest trying that to see if it makes any difference.

entry.title: SAP Digital Manufacturing – Inspection Characteristics Not Posted Due to Empty XSLT Configuration
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

we are currently working with SAP Digital Manufacturing (SAP DM) integrated with SAP S/4HANA 2023 SP03. While configuring the Order POD to report inspection characteristics using the "Quality Inspection Result" plugin, we’ve encountered an unexpected issue that I’d like to share with the community for feedback and support.

The Problem

We followed the official documentation for the plugin: Quality Inspection Results | SAP Help Portal

Despite having all relevant configurations in place, inspection characteristics are not being posted back to the system.

What We’ve Checked

We reviewed the integration guide: Inspection Characteristics Integration (Process Order and Production Order) | SAP Help Portal

Here’s what we’ve verified:

  • All QM settings in S/4HANA are correctly configured.
  • All CPI artifacts are deployed and up to date:
    • API_INSPECTIONCATALOG_SRV
    • API_INSPECTIONLOT_SRV
    • API_CHARCATTRIBUTECATALOG_SRV
  • The collaboration link COLLABORATION_SYNC_INSP_RESULT is using the correct directive: ERP_SYNC_INSP_RESULT_V2.

However, in the Integration Workflow "Inspection Results Recording", we noticed that:
No XSLT transformation is configured – all fields are empty.

Comparative Analysis

We compared this to another system (same software version) where the plugin works correctly. The only difference:
 

SystemRuntime Setup OnXSLT Config in Workflow
Working System13 Dec 2024Standard XSLT present
TDD System (Issue)20 Sep 2023XSLT fields empty
 
Working system with filled XSLT configuration.

 
TDD system with empty XSLT configuration.

As a workaround, we manually inserted the standard XSLT from the working system into the Custom-XSLT field of the faulty system – and it worked! Inspection characteristics were successfully posted.

Open Questions

  • Is this a known issue in SAP DM/CPI deployment and should i open an incident?
  • Is there a recommended way to ensure the XSLT configuration is correctly deployed during system setup?
  • Is there a standard deployment step that might have been skipped on the TDD system?

Any insights from the SAP team (@ManoelCosta, @Kevin_Hunter1) or fellow developers would be greatly appreciated. 🙏

Best regards,
Dominik

entry.title: SAP Service Cloud V2 Utilities Add-on - Mapping Extension fields in iFlow -> PART III
entry.content:
Introduction

This is the last part of the series of how to extend the replication of the Premise object with custom field.

Here is a link to the two prior blogs:

  • Part I - Extending Premise replication from SAP S/4HANA
  • Part II - Extending the Premise Object in SAP Service Cloud V2

The idea behind the 3 blogs is to describe the steps required to add a custom field to the Premise replication and then adding this to the Premise view in SAP Service Cloud V2. Below is a screenshot showing the field displayed:

 

In this blog I will cover how to perform the mapping for the IFlow. The standard delivered IFlow for Premise replication is designed to enable adding custom mappings, without changing it. This is clearly best practice, as this enables the project to keep getting updates to the standard delivered IFlow moving forward.

Using the above concept, the actual mapping is done in a custom IFlow that is called by the standard IFlow at runtime.

The configurations needed to achieve this are:

  • Configure the main IFlow to call a custom IFlow
  • Create and configure a custom IFlow for the mapping

 

Configure standard IFlow to enable extension

The idea behind the design of the standard delivered flow is to enable the ability to enhance the IFlow through configuration only. By doing this, it will be able to update the IFlow if or when updates are delivered by SAP.

Below is the standard delivered IFlow for Premise replication

 

The extensibility logic is performed in a custom IFlow. This custom IFlow is called based on a parameter configured in the standard IFlow.

In total 2 things are configured in the standard IFlow:

  • The address name of the custom IFlow where the extensibility is performed.
  • Set the parameter for extension to ‘true’

Open the IFlow and select ‘Configure’

There are different tabs available, and in the ‘Receiver’ tab the address of the custom IFlow is entered.

 

You can use the suggested address or create one of your own.

Remember the address is not the name of the custom IFlow, just the address when called.

 

Then on the ‘More’ tab, the call to a custom exit is set to ‘true’.

 

With the above, all changes required in the standard delivered IFlow are made. At this point the Premise replication IFlow will call the custom IFlow.

Note – without having the custom IFlow available, the Premise replication will fail when the main IFlow have been configured to call the custom flow.

 

Creating the Custom Iintegration Flow

The custom IFlow is called from the main IFlow via the Process Direct Adapter. This type of call is a synchronous call, meaning the main IFlow will not continue before the customer IFlow is completed.

The body and header of the main IFlow are shared to an IFlow called using the Process Direct Adapter. The Process Direct Adapter have two features for us here:

  1. In the customer IFlow we have access to the data from the Premise main IFlow
  2. If the data is updated in the custom IFlow, this will also be available for the main IFlow.

The effect of point 2 above is that when we update the body of the message in the custom IFlow, this is the same body that is used for the subsequent steps in the main IFlow.

The custom IFlow will have only one step, where we use a Groovy script to manipulate the data.

 

(1) For the entire IFlow a setting is needed to allow the header to be passed – This is done in ‘Runtime Configuration. This is important - I missed making this setting, and it took some time before I figured why no data was available I the custom IFlow.

The name of the allowed header is defined in the main IFlow and cannot be changed.

 

(2) In the Process Direct step, we define the address that was configured for the main IFlow.

For the above configuration I have kept the default name from the configuration in the main IFlow. If you changed the address in the main IFlow, you need to use the same address here.

 

(3) This is the Groovy script where we update the payload with custom fields.

The Groovy Script is covered in more details in the next section.

 

Create Groovy Script

It is possible to create the Groovy Script from scratch, but we have a sample script in the help documentation and here I have used this as my baseline: https://help.sap.com/docs/CX_NG_SVC/4d75f7ce63cc4e0a8ddacb060b8f8b54/83b38fd2a25d4fd69789eb4fed1cae43.html#loio7d6bb05a2ef94ece8142acb78149440b

In the appendix I have also added a copy of the Groovy Script I am using if you prefer to start with that.

The Groovy Script will only need to handle the logic to add the custom field. When the custom IFlow is called, we have already completed the mapping of all standard field. 

I will here try and give a short walkthrough of the Groovy script. Please remember from above description that we have access to the body and the header from the main IFlow. Just to re-cap:

Body: Is the data that eventually will be send to  SAP Service Cloud V2

Header: Contains the payload send from SAP S/4HANA, this contains all the data send in standard as well as the custom field added (covered in the first blog - Part I).

Below is a short description of the structure for the Groove Script.

First the body is read from the IFlow and placed into a variable called ‘json’.

Second, we read the payload send from SAP S/4HANA

The name ‘sourcePayload’ is the name used for the header configured in the main IFlow.

With these 2 steps we have the source and the target. The logic is simply to read the field from the source and place this into the target.

 

  1. Below we loop through each message. The IFlow is designed to handle that we send several Premises in the same message. The loop ensures that the mapping is happening for Premises in the payload.
  2. Here we extract the field needed and place this in a variable.
  3. Updating the body with the extracted variable.
  4. After looping through all Premises in the message, we create a variable that will be the new body. This include both all the original mapped fields from standard and now also the custom field mapped here.
  5. Setting the body equal the above variable
  6. Return the message to the main flow for further processing.
  7.  

 

Below a sample payload send from SAP S/4HANA:

 

The above structure, mapped to the line in the Groovy script reading the variable:

At this point the variable ‘my_roofType’ contains the value for the custom field, and using the above payload as a source, the value is ‘Solar Relevant’.

Next, we add the variable to the JSON structure that will be send to SAP Service Cloud V2.

From the prior blog (PART II), we added the field to SAP Service Cloud V2 and can see the extension structure:

 

 

In the Groovy script we write a value to this field:

 

  • Is the standard extension section available for all objects.
  • Is the name of the field we want to add the variable to in the structure.
  • The name of the variable.

After making these changes, the custom IFlow should be saved and then deployed. This marks the final step for endabling the custom field to be replicated to SAP Service Cloud V2.

 

Conclusion

This 3 parts series was meant to give an example of how to extend the Premise replication from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Service Cloud V2.  The idea was to give a starting point to investigate test this out on your own project.

 

 

 

APPENDIX

Complete Groovy Script used.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonOutput
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper
import groovy.util.XmlSlurper

def Message processData(Message message) {

  def body = message.getBody(java.io.Reader)
  def json = new JsonSlurper().parse(body)

  def xmlString = message.getHeader("sourcePayload",java.io.Reader)
  def xml = new XmlSlurper().parse(xmlString)

// Since there might be more then one Premise in the message,
// loop through all Premises in the message
  json.messageRequests.eachWithIndex { request, index ->

    // Extracting the custom field field from payload
    def my_roofType = xml.PremiseConnObjReplicateRequestMessage[index].PremiseConnectionObject.z_Roof_Type.text()


    // Adding the field to the extensions array of the
    // message send to SAP Service Cloud
    request.body.extensions = ["RoofType": my_roofType]
  }

// Create variable with modified body
  def modifiedJson = JsonOutput.toJson(json)
  
// Set entire body equal to above variable  
  message.setBody(modifiedJson)
  
// Return message to main IFlow  
  return message
}

entry.title: Re: Calculated columns: How to use TOTEXT for parameter with both string and number values
entry.content:
Hi Dries, PayScaleLevel is a foundation object. Foundation Objects are mostly wrongly identified as a measure . This will result in a number instead of text. Please change the semantic type to Dimension and try again. The TOTEXT function should not be needed as this field already is a string value.

I don't get any errors when using that field in a calculated column

Kind regards,

Jeroen

entry.title: How to use urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap.odm:2.0:User in IPS to IAS
entry.content:
Hi

 

We want to use this schema during writing to IAS 

urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap.odm:2.0:User
 So added it to my target transformation
 
 

Source in EntraID, target is IAS.

when running, I get this error

error=HTTP operation failed invoking https://MyIas.accounts.ondemand.com/scim/Users/f2a458 with statusCode: 500, Response: {"schemas":["urn:ietf:params:scim:api:messages:2.0:Error"],"status":"500","detail":"An internal error occurred."},


The payload does show the correct contents. 

 

Anybody knows what might be going wrong? Or to get more details on the 500 error?

 

 

Thanks

Sander

 
 
{
                "sourcePath": "$.jobTitle",
                "optional": true,
                "targetPath":"$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap.odm:2.0:User']['jobDetails']['jobTitle']"
            },

                "targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap.odm:2.0:User']['companyCode']['company']"

entry.title: Re: WEBI auto save feature
entry.content:
I'm not sure I understand the statements...

For the 5-digit number references ID of the existing document in the CMS, meaning it is already saved.

For the digit 0, this implies that placeholder for a new unsaved document that has no CMS ID yet.

I see autosave copies of public documents with "-0" in my ~WebIntelligence folder.  This does not seem to match what you indicate in these statements.

entry.title: Re: Integrating SAP Enterprise Continuous Testing by Tricentis Cloud with Jenkins: A Practical Guide
entry.content:
Hi Ingo,

you can use these API calls for Tricentis Test Automation for SAP integrated with SAP Cloud ALM, as well as for SAP Enterprise Continuous Testing by Tricentis. These are Open APIs that you can leverage regardless of the included version with SAP Cloud ALM of Tricentis Test Automation or the version within the SAP Solution Extensions Program.

Regarding the agents, executions via SAP Cloud ALM or, in this case, via Jenkins need Team Agents to be up and running. You could include the creation of a VM and running the Team Agents within the Jenkins pipeline as well. Local Agents won't work as they only work for temporary runs of test and don't save the log files of these test runs.

https://documentation.tricentis.com/sap/ect_cloud/en/content/admin_guide/agents_team.htm

https://documentation.tricentis.com/sap/ect_cloud/en/content/glossary.htm#private_agent

entry.title: New Brazilian Tax Reform - How to prepare your SBN solution for it (English Version)
entry.content:
Portuguese Version

           Hello!

           Starting today, we will begin a series of posts about the Brazilian Tax Reform, its impact on the SAP Business Network (SBN), and related topics, focusing on the activities and potential changes that will be necessary in your integrations, configurations, and customizations in the SBN.

           Future changes related to the solution will be communicated and monitored directly via official SBN releases by our product team.

 

1. Context

           Based on the Constitutional Amendment (EC) 132/2023 and Complementary Law (LC) 214/2025, the ICMS, ISS, IPI, PIS, and COFINS will be replaced by Dual Value Added Tax (VAT). The Dual VAT will consist of:

  • IBS (Tax on Goods and Services) – state and municipal competence, replacing ICMS and ISS
  • CBS (Contribution on Goods and Services) – federal competence, replacing PIS, COFINS and IPI

           The Selective Tax (IS) will also be created, which will be of federal competence and will apply to goods considered harmful to health or the environment, such as cigarettes and alcoholic beverages.

           Additionally, along with the tax changes, there will be a change in the composition of the CNPJ, which will become alphanumeric.

           According to the government publications, the change will be progressive, occurring gradually from 2026 to 2033.

 

2. Changes in SAP ERP

           SAP is working to meet all new requirements in advance and periodically publishing notes for system preparation. Information and links are available through two channels:

  • Regulatory Change Manager page dedicated to the topic 
  • Notes in detail and conversations with experts in the Workzone

Note: The page is authorized to the external public, but it is necessary to register and request access.

 

3. Changes in SAP Business Network for Buyer Companies

           If your company uses SAP Business Network as a buyer to transact with your suppliers, pay attention to the necessary changes highlighted below. Some definitions and actions must be taken directly by the buyer customers. See below:

 

3.1 Sending and Receiving Documents in ERP:

  • Initially, the buyer customer must define how it will handle the new taxes in the ERP, whether to update the current VATs, or to create new codes. 
  • It is also necessary to analyze if there are any developments related to relevant fields (CNPJ and taxes) for the enrichment of files (idocs, proxys, etc.) sent and received from SAP Business Network. If so, the customer must review the customizations made to ensure they will not be affected by the change in CNPJ format and the new taxes.

 

3.2 Customized Mappings:

  • The customer must review the custom mappings, if any, from sending and receiving documents. The goal is also to ensure that no impacts occur.

           Example of custom mapping for CNPJ: in this case, the customer sends the CNPJ in only one field in the idoc. In the mapping, the number is sent to various fields within the cmxl, such as ShipTo. An analysis must be realized to ensure that alphanumeric CNPJ will not affect the customization performed.

           Example of customized mapping for taxes: the standard segment for sending taxes is E1EDP01/E1EDP04. In this case, the customer sends the taxes in segment E1EDP05 and has a custom mapping to migrates the information. See the comparison:

            Standard – Sending taxes in the segment E1EDP01/E1EDP04, there is no need for customization in CIG:

           Current Taxes:

                     E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                           <MWSKZ>IPI</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>IPI Non-Deductible</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>
                     <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                           <MWSKZ>ICMS</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>ICMS Non-Deductible</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>

           Estimated idoc with new taxes:

                     <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                           <MWSKZ>CBS</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>CBS</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>
                     <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                           <MWSKZ>IBS</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>IBS</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>

           Customized – Sending taxes in the segment E1EDP01/E1EDP05, customization in CIG is needed.

           Current Taxes:

                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>IPI</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                     </E1EDP05>
                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>ICMS</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                     </E1EDP05>

 

           Estimated idoc with new taxes:

                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>CBS</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                     </E1EDP05>
                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>IBS</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                     </E1EDP05>

 

3.3 SBN Customization and Configuration:

  • Check in the project documentation if customizations were made on the SAP Business Network templates or in relevant fields for CNPJs and taxes. If so, contact your SAP account manager, as screen customizations are only customized by the SAP team.
  • If you have a customized tax list, review the list of taxes registered in the transaction rule “Require suppliers to choose from your list of valid tax values ” within the “Default Transaction Rules ” option.

Account Settings / Manage Profile / Default Transaction Rules / Require suppliers to choose from your list of valid tax values / Configure

 

  • The supplier customer who has SAP Business Network integration with the ERP must review their mappings and data transformation, ensuring that they are prepared to receive the new tax ID formats and new taxes (more information about this activity will be disclosed soon).

 

4. Changes in SAP Business Network for Supplier Companies

           If your company uses SAP Business Network as a supplier to transact with your buyers and has the platform integrated with your ERP, pay attention to the need for adjustments in data sending and receiving. We will soon release news detailing what potential adjustments your IT team or SAP partner should make.

 

Questions?

                If you have any questions, contact your SAP account manager to request specific help and review your solution.

entry.title: Re: Rework return to first activity in routing
entry.content:
Hi, 

If all resources are marked as process resources, any user must be able to complete as described in SAP Help. Otherwise, you might want to raise a ticket to investigate what is wrong.

You can have a specific POD to pull resources into the 'special' buffer operation, so if running normal operations in normal POD, start would start the next operation. If using 'special' operation POD, then Start button would have the PPD to sign off before starting, as you described is what you are looking for. Physically, normal POD would be used in the normal resource station, and the special POD would be used in the special resource station to pull SFCs to the buffer.

You can evaluate using DM Special Operation Activity capability, instead of adding the extra buffer 'special' operation into your original routing. See Pulling an SFC into a Special Operation Activity

Br, Manoel

entry.title: Re: GIS and SAP Integration – critical for Oil and Gas Companies
entry.content: Hello Satheesh, the VertiGIS Integrator is a standalone, message-based middleware between SAP and GIS. We have various endpoints available, such as SOAP, REST, ODATA, but also RFC calls or IDOC.

entry.title: Re: Calculated columns: How to use TOTEXT for parameter with both string and number values
entry.content:
Hi Dries,

I was able to reproduce your issue. It can be that picked the wrong column. External Name has an ID field and a Description Field. When I pick the ID field then I get the same error you have. But when I pick the Description field then the calculated column works fine.

Kind regards,

Jeroen

entry.title: Re: Rework return to first activity in routing
entry.content: This blog shows Special Operation setup in another context, but you can evaluate using Special Operations as your buffer, see: https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-sap/bring-done-sfcs-back-to-work/ba-p/13923872

entry.title: PO printing not considering the header text updates.
entry.content:
Hi Team,

Good day!!

Seams like this information not relevant to issue please find the following below pin points for analysis.

Standard document type NB:

In the Standard document type, updates to the PO header text are triggered automatically. This means that if we change any header text and save the PO, the updated text will appear in the output message printout.

In document type(ZMAP) MAPO case :

1.In the MAPO document type, updates to the PO header text are not triggered automatically. This means that if we change any header text and save the PO, the updated text will not appear in the output message printout.

2.We tried adding the output to the messages manually to print the updated text, but the PO print form is still not generating with the updates. 

 

Regards,

Sai.

entry.title: HR_INFOTYPE_OPERATION is deleting records it shouldn't
entry.content:
Hello !!!

I'm using HR_INFOTYPE_OPERATION to insert records in 2011, but it's inserting and also deleting a vacation record from 2001 (already paid) and adjusting it to 2006. Has anyone had this problem? Could you tell me a way to update infty 2011 without using this function?

Code: 

 

 

 

help me !!
